headline: Yankees Beat Indians, 3-2
summary: Curtis Granderson hit a go-ahead, two-run homer in the top of the eighth inning to lift the Yankees to a 3-2 win over the Cleveland Indians.

headline: ABC Entertainment President Quits
summary: ABC Entertainment President Stephen McPherson resigned amid difficulties  maintaining a solid roster of hit shows.

headline: Miners Likely to Skip Afghan Auction
summary: Afghanistan is preparing to auction off a round of iron ore, copper and natural gas deposits over the next year, but the major international miners aren't likely to go in until stability returns.

headline: Vote Set For 9/11 Health Bill
summary: After nearly nine years, House lawmakers are set to vote on a bill that would provide long-term health care to those who have become ill after working at the World Trade Center site.

headline: Blagojevich Lawyer Slams U.S. Case
summary: Rod Blagojevich's lead lawyer argued that the former Illinois governor never intended to sell the U.S. Senate seat. He was only seeking a deal that would benefit his legislative agenda.

headline: Citigroup's Best M&A Deal Ever?
summary: Sale of Phibro garnered criticism at the time, but the ex-unit weighed on the second-quarter profit of the buyer, Occidential Petroleum

headline: Barge Hits Oil Well Off Louisiana Coast
summary: An abandoned oil well was shooting a 100-foot plume of oil and gas into waters off the southeastern coast of Louisiana after it was hit by a tugboat pushing a barge.

headline: Payout to Investors in Reserve Fund Put on Hold
summary: Investors in Reserve Yield Plus Fund, many of whom have been clamoring to receive the remainder of their investments for nearly two years, are being told they will have to wait a bit longer.

headline: Kansas City Southern Profit Soars
summary: Kansas City Southern's profit soared as volume rebounded to pre-recession levels.

headline: Inside the Mitsubishi i-MiEV
summary: The Mitsubishi i-MiEV, currently available in Japan, is a compact four-door electric car designed for space efficiency and flexibility.

headline: Dow Edges Up 12.26 Points
summary: Stocks finished the day with a mixed result, as a weak consumer-confidence reading offset the latest round of strong corporate earnings.

headline: Valero Swings to Profit
summary: Valero Energy posted a $583 million profit, breaking a string of quarterly losses as its petroleum-product sales rose and costs fell.

headline: Affiliated Managers Profit More Than Doubles
summary: Affiliated Managers scooped up more fees from some of the hedge-fund businesses it owns stakes in.

headline: Disney to Purchase Social-Game Maker Playdom for $563.2 Million
summary: Walt Disney Co. confirmed it will purchase online social-network gaming company Playdom Inc., agreeing to pay at least $563.2 million.

headline: No-Frills Cuban Cuisine
summary: The long line moves quickly at Margon near Times Square, which cooks down-home Cuban dishes amid orange Formica tables and plastic cutlery.

headline: Pictures of the Day: July 27
summary: In today's photos, a California woman rails against officials' high pay, a man wades through oil-slicked waters in China, a boy plays in mud in Pakistan and more.

headline: SAP Profit Increases 15%
summary: SAP's profit rose 15%, driven by higher software sales in the Americas. But other markets didn't perform as well.

headline: Uncertainty Sinks BP Shares
summary: BP shares fell as investors noted that considerable uncertainty surrounds the company even after the publication of second-quarter earnings and the ouster of its chief executive.

headline: Crude Falls Back From $80 Barrier
summary: Crude futures retreated from early gains, again failing to reach $80 a barrel, leaving oil to fall into the red on weakening economic data and indecisive equities markets.

headline: In Search of This Year's Chris Johnson
summary: Fantasy experts are flummoxed by young, promising players like Kansas City's Jamaal Charles, who might post huge numbers or get caught in a platoon.

headline: Localiza Expands Fleet
summary: Brazilian car-rental agency Localiza said it will spend $1.4 billion to renew and expand its rental-car fleet, gearing up for a continuation of the nation's robust recovery from last year's recession.

headline: U.K. Court Freezes Deal Proceeds
summary: The U.K. High Court has frozen $110 million from the proceeds of Midland Resources Holding's sale of Ukraine steelmaker Zaporizhstal.

headline: Cummins Net Quadruples
summary: Cummins posted a sharply higher profit as the engine maker's sales rose 32%.

headline: Lion to Buy BC Partners' Picard
summary: Lion Capital will buy Picard Surgelés, the French frozen-foods company being sold by BC Partners, in a deal valued at $1.94 billion.

headline: U.K. Details Tax Reform Plan
summary: The Treasury launched a series of consultations, including a possible easing of rules that affect the taxation of foreign profits of U.K.-based companies.

headline: Occidental Exposure
summary: None

headline: Rite Aid Settles FTC Privacy Case
summary: Rite Aid will pay $1 million to settle potential violations of  government privacy rules after the FTC said it failed to protect customers' and employees' financial and medical information.

headline: CEO's Retirement Shakes Up Southern's Executive Ranks
summary: Southern Co. said President and Chief Executive David Ratcliffe will retire later this year, prompting the shuffling of several executives into new roles.

headline: St. Jude Says Ex-Executive Violated Pact by Joining Medtronic
summary: St. Jude Medical believes a former top executive with access to "copious amounts" of confidential information violated an employment agreement by leaving and quickly joining heart-device rival Medtronic.

headline: Domino's Profit Rises; Pizza Hut Cuts Prices
summary: Domino's reported a 56% increase in profit, citing a revamped pizza recipe and marketing campaign that are bringing in new customers. Pizza Hut also announced that it was cutting its pizza prices.

headline: Lockheed, L-3 Post Profit
summary: Lockheed Martin and L-3 Communications each reported a quarterly profit but adjusted their outlooks, anticipating Pentagon cost-cutting measures that some worry may cut into profit margins.

headline: Luxury-Car Sales Recover
summary: Luxury-car makers boosted their outlooks for the year as demand recovered faster than expected after a woeful 2009, fueled by a growing number of affluent Chinese customers and a rebound in the U.S.

headline: HTC Plans Mainland China Push
summary: HTC plans to introduce four smartphone models in China under its own name amid intensifying competition with Apple and other rivals.

headline: U.K. Fines Former Northern Rock Official
summary: Britain's financial regulator has banned the former finance director of mortgage lender Northern Rock and fined him $495,552 for misreporting figures on loan arrears.

headline: Protest Shuts London BP Stations
summary: Greenpeace shut down the fuel pumps at dozens of BP petrol stations in London, in a protest timed to BP's quarterly report and management shake-up.

headline: JFE Plans India Investment
summary: JFE Holdings plans to buy just under 15% of India's JSW Steel for $1.04 billion as part of a strategic tie-up.

headline: Banks Lift European Stocks
summary: European stocks closed higher, led by a surge in the banking sector after investors breathed a sigh of relief that future bank regulations won't be as tough as anticipated.

headline: Hayward Expresses Sadness on Exit
summary: Hayward defended his response to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill but acknowledged that it was time to step down "for the good of BP."

headline: Lufthansa Plane Crashes in Riyadh
summary: A Lufthansa cargo plane caught fire during landing and crashed at Riyadh's airport in Saudi Arabia, injuring the pilot and his assistant.

headline: Turkey Cuts Inflation Outlook
summary: The central bank issued a benign forecast on inflation, interest rates and a gathering economic recovery as the country's stock prices were soaring to a record high.

headline: San Miguel Seeks $1.6 Billion
summary: San Miguel plans to raise up to $1.6 billion to finance planned investments and acquisitions for the food and beverage conglomerate.

headline: Office Depot Loss Narrows
summary: Office Depot's second-quarter loss narrowed as the office-products retailer cut operating costs, but revenue fell.

headline: Investors Unconvinced Despite Strong Quarterly Revenues
summary: U.S. businesses  are having a hard time hammering home the message that earnings and revenue are  strong.

headline: Forex Is Back, But Different
summary: Judging by the growing turnover in their market, foreign-exchange traders have had a very busy and no doubt lucrative past three years. Yet reports also show notable volatility within the three-year period.

headline: Japan's Bond Yields Fall on Fears of More BOJ Easing
summary: Japanese-government-bond yields mostly fell as stable U.S. Treasury yields fueled expectations the Bank of Japan may ease policy further.

headline: Teva Results Reflect Strong Sales for MS Drug
summary: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries said second-quarter profit rose 53% on strong sales of flagship multiple-sclerosis drug Copaxone and growth of its generic operations, especially in North America.

headline: Euro-Zone Loan Growth Picks Up
summary: Monetary trends in the euro area brightened, as the pace of credit growth to the private sector edged up to its highest rate in nearly a year.

headline: Merck in Talks for China Partnership
summary: Merck is in talks with China's Sinopharm for a venture to market vaccines and, potentially, Merck drugs.

headline: PBOC Is Confident Despite Slower Growth
summary: China's central bank struck a confident note, saying the country's current economic slowdown is beneficial for long-term sustainable growth, and there is little risk of a "double-dip" recession.

headline: Malaysia's Promise
summary: John Malott's op-ed ("What Anwar's Trial Means For Malaysia," July 20) includes a fairly accurate description of Malaysia as "an Asian economic success story, a moderate Islamic country and aspiring democracy, and a multiracial society in which harmony prevails.

headline: Danone Boosts Sales Target
summary: French dairy-products company Danone slightly raised its full-year sales outlook even as net profit dropped 10% in the first half because last year's result was lifted by an asset sale.

headline: DuPont's Net Jumps
summary: Chemical maker DuPont's profit nearly tripled as sales surged in most of its businesses and costs decreased. The company also raised its full-year earnings forecast.

headline: Occidental Net Rises 56%
summary: Occidental Petroleum said its earnings rose 56% as the oil-and-gas company saw stronger prices and sales volume.

headline: Apple Updates iMacs, Unveils Trackpad
summary: Apple unveiled its new line of iMac desktop computers, which feature increased processing speeds and can use a new trackpad similar to those on its laptops.

headline: China's Currency Glasnost Has Its Limits
summary: All of a sudden, China's central bank can't stop talking about the country's currency regime.

headline: Japan's Budget Looks Busted From The Start
summary: This time it will be different. That's what the new Japanese administration wants you to believe.

headline: Daiwa Reports Loss
summary: Daiwa Securities reported its second consecutive quarterly loss due to sharply lower commission fees from investment banking and a significant drop in trading revenue.

headline: Pentagon Eyes Analyst in Leaks
summary: Military investigators are checking computers used by Bradley Manning, a U.S. Army intelligence analyst charged with leaking classified information, to see if he is the source of thousands of documents published by WikiLeaks.

headline: Thoratec Scraps Plan to Sell Unit to Danaher
summary: Thoratec and Danaher agreed to scrap their agreement under which Danaher would have bought Thoratec's division that makes diagnostic tools and blood-monitoring systems.

headline: European Bank CDS Costs Closest to Corporate Index Since March
summary: The cost of insuring senior debt of European banks and insurers against default Tuesday was closer to the benchmark for a range of bank and nonbank borrowers.

headline: Smoke Covers Moscow Amid Record Heat
summary: Wreathed in smoke from underground fires, Moscow recorded its hottest day ever as large parts of Russia endured severe drought.

headline: Euro Gives Up Early Gains
summary: The euro surrendered an 11-week high against the dollar after better-than-expected U.S. home-prices data helped the greenback recoup some its earlier losses.

headline: Sands China Taps Managers
summary: Sands China, a publicly traded unit of Las Vegas Sands, named new executives in the wake of its CEO's dismissal Friday.

headline: Sales at Mercedes Lift Daimler
summary: Daimler swung to a net profit and lifted its target for full-year earnings before interest and tax, fueled by a speedy recovery in the luxury-car market.

headline: Lexmark Profit Soars
summary: Lexmark's earnings jumped as the printer company posted fewer charges and demand continued to improve from the prior year's weak levels.

headline: AmerisourceBergen Net Rises
summary: AmerisourceBergen's profit jumped 37% on better-than-expected revenue growth, largely driven by its generic-pharmaceuticals operations.

headline: BE Aerospace Profit Climbs
summary: None

headline: RBI Moves to Curb Inflation
summary: In a move to quell double-digit inflation, India's central bank raised its lending and borrowing rates on Tuesday. Some snapshots of its likely impact.

summary: The federal government settled charges against Spanish-language media firm Univision Communications Inc. over allegations that some of its radio stations or employees secretly accepted payment to play some songs more frequently.

summary: The Afghan war documents published by WikiLeaks appear to contain evidence of war crimes,  WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange told a news conference in London.

headline: India Introduces Bill to Resolve Regulatory Disputes
summary: India's federal government introduced a bill to set up a panel, a first of its kind, which will be the final decision-making authority for any disputes arising between the country's financial regulators.

headline: Germany balks at new Basel accord
summary: Germany refused—at least for now—to sign on to parts of an agreement on the latest round of an evolving international accord on bank-capital standards being negotiated by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, according to officials close to the talks.

headline: Wall Street Fails to Lift All Asia
summary: Asian markets ended mixed as Hong Kong and Australian stocks advanced on U.S. earnings optimism while Chinese shares declined. The Shanghai index slid 0.5%.

headline: Kargil Dead Remembered
summary: Citizens of India paid tribute to the soldiers who died during the Kargil conflict on the occasion of the 'Kargil Vijay Diwas' on Monday. Some snapshots.

headline: Hindustan Unilever Profit Slips
summary: Hindustan Unilever said net profit for the fiscal first quarter slipped 1.8%, missing estimates, as the company cut prices and spent more on advertising, sacrificing profitability to grow sales volume.

headline: Two Years Out
summary: Two years before the 2010 Olympic Games open in London, a huge stadium, a wave-shaped aquatics center and other venues continue to come together.

headline: WikiLeaks Publishes Military Files
summary: Thousands of secret military documents were released Sunday by the web-based organization, WikiLeaks.

headline: MakeMyTrip Files for $100 Million IPO
summary: MakeMyTrip, which operates India's largest travel website, MakeMyTrip.com, announced plans to sell up to an estimated $100 million of stock in the U.S. through an initial public offering.

summary: IIn today's photos, a Navy sailor stands on the USS Harry Truman, a new bridge makes its way up New York's East River, donkey races and more.

headline: Japanese Lenders Looking West Face Challenges
summary: In Japan, the heady days of the late 1980s are back—at least for the country's leading banks.

headline: Philippines' Aquino Seeks Partnership
summary: Philippines President Benigno Aquino III said that renewed investor confidence will create jobs and bolster the economy, despite a widening budget deficit.

headline: IAG Warns Profit To Drop 50%

summary: French police questioned Liliane Bettencourt as part of a preliminary investigation into allegations of illegal campaign financing that have roiled President Nicolas Sarkozy and his government for two months.

headline: Husain Haqqani: An Ally of Necessity
summary: Over the past nine years, more Pakistani than NATO troops have lost their lives fighting the Taliban.

headline: IMF Sees Yuan as Undervalued

headline: Soros Eyes Stake in Bombay Exchange

headline: Some Politicians Don't Care About Economic Accuracy
summary: Michael J. Boskin opines that because President Barack Obama grossly exaggerates the success of his stimulus package, his credibility is somehow damaged ("Obama's Economic Fish Stories," op-ed, July 21). It is not.

headline: No Wonder the Market Is Yo-Yoing
summary: Regarding Andy Kessler's "The Yo-Yo Market and You" (op-ed, July 16): As he points out, the new taxes and potential seizures pending under the current administration increase uncertainty.

headline: SEC Helps Steer Ford Back to Market

headline: EU Adds IBM to Target List
summary: Reanimating long-dormant scrutiny of IBM, EU antitrust authorities said they have opened formal investigations into Big Blue's conduct in the market for powerful mainframe computers.

summary: What's News: World-Wide for July 27, 2010

headline: What Is Lost When Works are Trophies
summary: Egon Schiele's "Portrait of Wally" is destined to be remembered as a Nazi-era artifact rather than a work of 20th-century modernism.

headline: China Fuels Trade Tension, Report Says
summary: China's drive to support domestic technologies is likely to continue to cause trade disputes and political tensions, says a Chamber of Commerce report.

summary: Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed documents from an arbitration case that sought to prove that Lance Armstrong used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Tancredo Bid Roils Colorado GOP
summary: Former Rep. Tom Tancredo, once a tea-party favorite, upset members of the movement and Colorado Republicans by announcing a third-party gubernatorial bid.

headline: The Cashless Take the LIRR
summary: The Long Island Rail Road is finding a growing number of credit-card-reliant young people are boarding trains from the Hamptons without cash and without pre-paid tickets, creating hassles for conductors.

headline: Putting Out Jumbo Welcome Mat
summary: Banks are competing for jumbo-loan business with new products and attractive options for borrowers.

headline: EPA Focuses on Poor, Minorities
summary: The Environmental Protection Agency outlined a plan for placing special emphasis on the health of low-income and minority populations when drafting rules.

headline: Raymond James Must Buy Back Securities
summary: An arbitration panel ordered two units of Raymond James Financial to buy back $2.5 million in auction-rate securities from an investor.

headline: Ex-Spy Depicted as Taliban Link
summary: U.S. intelligence reports paint a picture of Hamid Gul and the Pakistani spy agency that he headed in the late 1980s as working in recent years to attack U.S. interests in Afghanistan.

headline: Corn Drops on Lack of Threat to Supplies
summary: Corn prices slid on forecasts for weather in the Midwest that is conducive to a boost in supplies.

headline: Tribune Faces New Hurdle in Report
summary: A bankruptcy investigator lent credence to claims that Tribune's $8.2 billion buyout deal in 2007 left it too shaky to survive, throwing up another possible hurdle to the media company's efforts to exit bankruptcy protection after nearly 20 months.

headline: Mayor Gets Results on Towing
summary: New York will retain the power to tow parking scofflaws' cars after Albany officials negotiated an amendment to a bill that could have put in jeopardy the city's towing program.

headline: Happy Couples, Go Ahead and Fight
summary: Couples fight. The good news: If you fight the right way it can actually make your relationship happier and healthier.

headline: Bulls Bet on Builder Stocks
summary: Options traders flocked to home builders after new data showed home buying surged last month from May's depressed levels.

headline: Lufthansa Seeks Savor in the Sky
summary: Chefs from the German airline are using a chopped up jet as a laboratory to study the decline of haute cuisine at high altitude.

headline: 'Old GM' Assets Linger
summary: The winding down of GM's "bad assets" is dragging on, with only one former factory and a few other properties finding a second life a year into the process.

headline: Step Right Up and Beat the Mets
summary: Mets fans have been emotionally tortured this season. It's been down and up, down and up, and now, crushingly, down and down, with no upswing in sight.

headline: Forex Trade Returns to Precrisis Levels
summary: The currency-trading business expanded at a double-digit rate in the six months through April, marking a cautious return to business as usual.

headline: Florida State Ponders Heisman
summary: Florida State is endorsing Christian Ponder as the Heisman favorite,. Plus, Joe Saunders's wins helped push through the trade for Dan Haren.

headline: The Politics of Garbage
summary: Of all the recent cuts to local budgets, one in particular is raising a stink: scalebacks in garbage collection.

headline: Russell Simmons Seeks to Grow New Artists
summary: Hip-hop mogul Russell Simmons's Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation is launching a program this summer to help discover and cultivate the next wave of aspiring artists in urban photography and multimedia art.

headline: Storm-Tossed Boom Threatens Marshes
summary: To keep crude oil out of Louisiana's sensitive marshes, workers have spread barriers known as boom in unprecedented amounts. Now the marshes face a new threat—from the boom itself.

headline: The Do-It-Yourself House Call
summary: Insurer-endorsed remote-monitoring technology leads heart patients to take their own readings at home.

headline: Reports Suggest Iran Ties to Extremists
summary: U.S. officials and Middle East analysts said some of the most explosive information contained in the WikiLeaks documents detail Iran's alleged ties to the Taliban and al Qaeda.

headline: Robert M. Kimmitt and Matthew J. Slaughter: The Foreign Investment Solution for American Jobs
summary: You know that battery plant in Michigan the president visited the other day? It's Korean-owned.

headline: Bulluck Plans to Plug Big Hole
summary: Keith Bulluck says he's fully ready to man the Giants' middle linebacker spot, and he doesn't see his tenure with the Giants ending with his one-year contract.

headline: Change, Yes, but Where's the Hope?
summary: Regarding Kimberley Strassel's "About That Financial Reform 'Victory' " (Potomac Watch, July 16): Looking back to 2008, candidate Barack Obama and the "progressives" promised change.

headline: Developing Markets Lift Reckitt Profit
summary: Consumer-products giant Reckitt Benckiser posted a 23% rise in second-quarter net profit Monday, despite declining sales in Europe, but failed to issue its customary upgrade to full-year guidance.

headline: Indonesia Plans Subway to Ease Traffic
summary: Indonesian leaders are making plans to build the world's next major subway system, in an effort to battle Jakarta's deepening traffic woes.

headline: Quantifying the Boss's 'Seinfeld' Legacy
summary: In his 10 non-finale appearances, the Steinbrenner character hired, fired, traded or promoted eight people, did or said 13 completely irrational things by our count and referred to himself as "Big Stein" five times.

headline: He's Long, Lean and Unlimited
summary: The Knicks are hopeful that Anthony Randolph, recently acquired from the Warriors, will come close to fulfilling the expectations that have shadowed him since Golden State drafted him in 2008.

headline: Trying to Unplug and Drive
summary: The I-MiEV, set to arrive in fall 2011, promises great storage space and a greener driving experience—if you can handle the "range anxiety."

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Peter Wehner writes that lawmakers who are suggesting secession in response to President Obama's policies are being stupid and reckless.

headline: EU Loses Ruling on Electronics Tariffs
summary: A WTO panel has ruled that European Union tariffs on imports of electronics products violate an international trade agreement.

headline: Rent a Leaf From Enterprise
summary: Enterprise Rent-A-Car will announce that it is buying 500 electric cars from Nissan, beginning in January when they become widely available.

headline: Ruling Lets Owners Alter iPhone Software
summary: Apple's control over its iPhone and other devices via iTunes store was undercut Monday by a federal ruling legalizing jailbreaking, or altering the devices to install unauthorized software.

headline: U.K. Details Finance Overhaul
summary: The U.K. government provided more details on a sweeping plan to consolidate and enhance its financial regulatory structure by transferring more powers to the Bank of England.

headline: Legg Mason Net Falls As Funds Pulled Out
summary: Legg Mason's quarterly profit fell 4.2% as investors continued to pull funds from the asset manager and investments wilted in the stock-market decline.

headline: Rosneft Net Jumps 59%
summary: Russia's largest oil producer Rosneft said net profit rose 59% thanks to higher oil prices and increased crude output at its Vankor field.

headline: U.S. Soldiers Charged With Fuel Theft
summary: U.S. investigators arrested two U.S. soldiers and suspended a pair of Afghan trucking companies on suspicions they helped the soldiers steal $1.6 million in fuel from a military base in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: An Imperfect CEO Readies His Exit
summary: When he testified to Congress last month, an apologetic Tony Hayward declared: "To be sure, neither I nor the company is perfect." There seems to be a strange determination to prove as much.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for July 27

headline: JFK Bomb Plot TrialConcludes
summary: Prosecutors used their closing arguments in the JFK Airport bomb-plot trial to portray the defendants as men determined to carry out a deadly attack in support of al Qaeda.

headline: EU Stress Tests Had Glitches
summary: The bank stress tests conducted by EU regulators have revealed a small number of glitches, but the architect of the tests said that these didn't call into question the overall integrity of the tests.

headline: 'Hughes Rules' a Work in Progress
summary: The Yankees are still trying to figure out how to manage Phil Hughes's workload to prevent overuse.

headline: The Federal Reserve Can't Beat Bad Policy
summary: In his "Capital" column ("The Lay of the Land, as Seen From Bernanke's Perch," U.S. News, July 21) David Wessel opines on the limited arrows the Federal Reserve has left in its quiver.

headline: An Uncommon Deal Battle Ends in Singapore
summary: In a rare example of a hostile move by a sovereign-wealth fund, Malaysia's Khazanah Holdings offered US$2.6 billion to buy the stake in Singapore hospital operator Parkway Holdings Ltd. it doesn't already own, prompting India's Fortis Healthcare Ltd. to abandon its own takeover efforts and relinquish control of the company.
